div.p: During the school closures due to COVID-19 this page will be dedicated to resources for parents and students as they pursue learning opportunities at home.
Necesitas ayuda en español? Por favor, envía un correo electrónico a vposada@eesd.net.
Your kids are at home, now what? Probably the most important thing you can do is to maintain a consistent routine for your children while they are at home.

ul.li: Getting up and dressed for “school” in the morning will help them feel like it’s a normal day.
Aim to establish a routine starting Monday (3/23). It might take a fews days to get used to it, but stick with it!

It’s more important to be CONSISTENT and do a short amount of academic practice every day than it is to try to engage in long, challenging tasks every few days. Consistent practice every day, particularly in reading and writing, will pay off greater dividends over time.

Working in short bursts with frequent breaks may help children as well (set a timer so they know when they get a break). Below is a suggested schedule, feel free to adjust according to what works for your family.
Save entertainment screen time until after learning time and chores.
Most of what you need you can access through clever.com
i-Ready rule of thumb: K-3 students 30 min./day; 4-8th students 45 min./day.

Help your children focus on the positives of more time together as a family. Perhaps it’s time to tackle a project as a family that you’ve been putting off, play board games, assign daily chores so everyone helps out, read a book together, do a big puzzle, etc.

div.p: Check out our sample schedule links for K-2, 3-5, 6-8!

p.a: Daily Schedule for Kindergarten-2nd Grade (printable PDF)

li.a: Resources for Parents as they Discuss Covid-19
Resource to Support Social Emotional Learning at Home
Apps to Promote Social Emotional Learning

h2.a: Resources for Parents as they Discuss Covid-19

ul.li: PBS Kids: How to Talk to Your Kids About Coronavirus

span.span: Just for Kids: A Comic Exploring the New Coronavirus from NPR:

span.a: What Kids Want To Know About Coronavirus: An Original Comic : Goats and Soda

ul.li: The Yucky Bug by Julia Cook: The Yucky Bug by Julia Cook

span.a: Resources for Families During the Coronavirus Pandemic

h2.a: Resource to Support Social Emotional Learning at Home

div.p: Resources to support Social Emotional Learning at home:

li.a: HeartSmart Family At Home Resources And Activities
Copy of SEL at Home K-2 - Listed on TpT -

h2.a: Apps to Promote Social Emotional Learning

p.strong: Apps to Promote Social Emotional Learning

ul.li: Parachute: a user-friendly, research-backed parenting app that provides easy access to solutions for common parenting challenges
Mind Yeti: a mindfulness app with guided sessions that help kids destress, focus, get along with others, and relax
Confident Parents, Confident Kids: a site with parent and child resources that support social-emotional development
Parent Toolkit: a site with information and articles about all aspects of child development
Online Programs for Children with Anxiety | Kids Anxiety Relief Go Zen is a site with online social emotional learning programs for children ages 5-15

p.strong: Resources to support parents regarding Internet Safety (there will be potential of increased screen time during school closures):

p.a: COVID-19 School Closures: Our Best Tips for Digital Safety, Emotional Wellness and Family Time
How To Protect Your Child Online, According To A Cybersecurity Expert

div.p: Crisis Mental Health Resources (please note that many mental health agencies and private practice clinicians may have to close. The following is a list of crisis mental health resources and services).

ul.li: Hill Country CARE Center: (530) 691-4446, 1401 Gold St
Dignity Health Mercy Medical Center: (530) 225-6000, 2175 Rosaline Dr.
Shasta Regional Medical Center: (530)244-5400, 1100 Butte St. Redding
Suicide Prevention Line: 1-800-273-8255
One Safe Place (domestic violence support and resources) (530)244-0118, 2250 Benton Dr. Redding

div.h2: How to Log On to Chromebooks at Home
div.p:
To access CLEVER click HERE
For assitance with logging in, email help@eesd.net.

div.div:
How to Login to Child’s Student Account on a School Assigned Chromebook
K-2 Students:
Student login is students first initial of their first and last name + student number
Example: Jane Doe Student Number: 12345
jd12345@eesd.net
Student password is the student’s lunch number twice
1234512345
3rd-12th Grade Students: Student login and password are the same that student uses at school
